p.hi: NEW MODULI SPACES OF POINTED CURVES
AND PENCILS OF FLAT CONNECTIONS
A. Losev11, Yu. Manin22
Institute of Theoretical and Experimental Physics, Moscow, Russia
Max–Planck–Institut für Mathematik, Bonn, Germany
Dedicated to William Fulton on the occasion of his 60th birthday

body.p: Abstract. It is well known that formal solutions to the Associativity Equations are the same as cyclic algebras over the homology operad (H*⁢(M¯0,n+1))subscript𝐻subscript¯𝑀0𝑛1 of the moduli spaces of n𝑛–pointed stable curves of genus zero. In this paper we establish a similar relationship between the pencils of formal flat connections (or solutions to the Commutativity Equations) and homology of a new series L¯nsubscript¯𝐿𝑛 of pointed stable curves of genus zero. Whereas M¯0,n+1subscript¯𝑀0𝑛1 parametrizes trees of ℙ1superscriptℙ1’s with pairwise distinct nonsingular marked points, L¯nsubscript¯𝐿𝑛 parametrizes strings of ℙ1superscriptℙ1’s stabilized by marked points of two types. The union of all L¯nsubscript¯𝐿𝑛’s forms a semigroup rather than operad, and the role of operadic algebras is taken over by the representations of the appropriately twisted homology algebra of this union.

p.hi: 0. Introduction and plan of the paper

body.p: One of the remarkable basic results in the theory of the Associativity Equations (or Frobenius manifolds) is the fact that their formal solutions are the same as cyclic algebras over the homology operad (H*⁢(M¯0,n+1))subscript𝐻subscript¯𝑀0𝑛1 of the moduli spaces of n𝑛–pointed stable curves of genus zero. This connection was discovered by physicists, who observed that the data of both types come from models of topological string theories. Precise mathematical treatment was given in [KM] and [KMK].

In this paper we establish a similar relationship between the pencils of formal flat connections (or solutions to the Commutativity Equations: see 3.1–3.2 below) and homology of a new series L¯nsubscript¯𝐿𝑛 of pointed stable curves of genus zero. Whereas M¯0,n+1subscript¯𝑀0𝑛1 parametrizes trees of ℙ1superscriptℙ1’s with pairwise distinct nonsingular marked points, L¯nsubscript¯𝐿𝑛 parametrizes strings of ℙ1superscriptℙ1’s, and all marked points with exception of two are allowed to coincide (see the precise definitions in 1.1 and 2.1). Moreover, the union of all L¯nsubscript¯𝐿𝑛’s forms a semigroup rather than operad, and the role of operadic algebras is taken over by the representations of the appropriately twisted homology algebra of this union: see precise definitions in 3.3.
This relationship was discovered on a physical level in [Lo1], [Lo2]. Here we give a mathematical treatment of some of the main issues raised in these papers.
This paper is structured as follows.

In §1 we introduce the notion of (A,B)𝐴𝐵–pointed curves whose combinatorial structure generalizes that of strings of projective lines described above. We then describe a construction of “adjoining a generic black point” which allows us to produce families of such curves and their moduli stacks inductively. This is a simple variation of one of the arguments due to F. Knudsen [1].

In §2 we define and study the spaces L¯nsubscript¯𝐿𝑛 for which we give two complementary constructions. The first one identifies L¯nsubscript¯𝐿𝑛 with one of the moduli spaces of pointed curves. The second one exhibits L¯nsubscript¯𝐿𝑛 as a well–known toric manifold associated with the polytope called permutohedron in [Ka2]. These constructions put L¯nsubscript¯𝐿𝑛 into two quite different contexts and suggest generalizations in different directions.

As moduli spaces, L¯nsubscript¯𝐿𝑛 become components of the extended modular operad which we define and briefly discuss in §4. We expect that there exists an appropriate extension of the Gromov–Witten invariants producing algebras over extended operads involving gravitational descendants.

As toric varieties, (L¯n)subscript¯𝐿𝑛 form one of the several series related to the generalized flag spaces of classical groups: see [GeSe]. It would be interesting to generalize to other series our constructions.

In this paper we use the toric description in order to prove for L¯nsubscript¯𝐿𝑛’s an analog of Keel’s theorem (Theorem 2.7.1) and its extension (Theorem 2.9), crucial for studying representations of the twisted homology algebra.
This twisted homology algebra H*⁢Tsubscript𝐻𝑇 and its relationship with pencils of formal flat connections are discussed in §3, which contains the main result of this paper: Theorem 3.3.1.

Acknowledgement. Yu. Manin is grateful to M. Kapranov who, after having seen the formula χ⁢(L¯n)=n!𝜒subscript¯𝐿𝑛𝑛, suggested that L¯nsubscript¯𝐿𝑛 must be the toric variety associated with the permutohedron.

body.p: 1.2. Remarks. a) If we put in this definition B=∅𝐵, we will get the usual notion of an A𝐴–pointed (pre)stable curve whose structure sections are not allowed to intersect pairwise. Now we divide the sections into two groups: “white” sections xi,i∈Asubscript𝑥𝑖𝑖𝐴 are not allowed to intersect any other section, whereas “black” sections xj,j∈Bsubscript𝑥𝑗𝑗𝐵 cannot intersect white ones, but otherwise are free and can even pairwise coincide. (However, both types of sections are not allowed to intersect singularities of fibres).

If we take in this definition one–element set B={*}𝐵, we will get a natural bijection between (A,{*})𝐴–pointed curves and (A∪{*},∅)𝐴–pointed curves. If card⁢B≥2,card𝐵2 the two notions become essentially different.

b) The dual modular graph of a geometric fibre is defined in the same way as in the usual case (for the conventions we use see [Ma], III.2). Tails now can be of two types, and we may refer to them and their marks as “black” and “white” ones as well. Combinatorial type of a geometric fiber is, by definition, the isomorphism class of the respective modular graph with (A,B)𝐴𝐵–marking of its tails.
c) Let T→S→𝑇𝑆 be an arbitrary base change. It produces from any (A,B)𝐴𝐵–pointed (stable) curve (1.2) over S𝑆 another (A,B)𝐴𝐵–pointed (stable) curve over T𝑇: (CT;xi,T).subscript𝐶𝑇subscript𝑥𝑖𝑇
1.3. A construction. In this subsection, we start with an (A,B)𝐴𝐵–pointed curve (1.1) and produce from it another (A,B′)𝐴superscript𝐵′–pointed curve:

The base of the new curve will be S′:=C.assignsuperscript𝑆′𝐶 There will be one extra black mark, say, *, so that B′=B∪{*}superscript𝐵′𝐵. The new curve and sections will be produced in two steps. At the first step we make the base change C→S→𝐶𝑆 as in 1.2 c), obtaining an (A,B)𝐴𝐵–pointed curve X:=C×SCassign𝑋subscript𝑆𝐶𝐶, with sections xi,C.subscript𝑥𝑖𝐶 We then add the extra section Δ:C→C×SC:Δ→𝐶subscript𝑆𝐶𝐶 which is the relative diagonal, and mark it by *. We did not yet produce an (A,B′)𝐴superscript𝐵′–pointed curve over S′=Csuperscript𝑆′𝐶, because the extra black section can (and generally will) intersect both singular points of the fibres and white sections as well.

At the second step of the construction, we remedy this by birationally modifying C×SC→C→subscript𝑆𝐶𝐶𝐶 as in [Kn1], Definition 2.3. More precisely, we define C′:=Proj⁢Sym⁢𝒦assignsuperscript𝐶′ProjSym𝒦 as the relative projective spectrum of the symmetric algebra of the sheaf 𝒦𝒦 on X=C×SC𝑋subscript𝑆𝐶𝐶 defined as the cokernel of the map
Here 𝒥Δsubscript𝒥Δ is the 𝒪Xsubscript𝒪𝑋–ideal of ΔΔ, and 𝒥Δ⁢ˇsubscript𝒥Δˇabsent is its dual sheaf considered as a subsheaf of meromorphic functions, as in [Kn1], Lemma 2.2 and Appendix.

We claim now that we get an (A,B′)𝐴superscript𝐵′–pointed curve, because Knudsen’s treatment of his modification can be directly extended to our case. In fact, the modification we described is nontrivial only in a neighbourhood of those points, where ΔΔ intersects either singular points of the fibres, or A𝐴–sections. The B𝐵–sections do not intersect these neighborhoods, if they are small enough, and do not influence the local analysis due to Knudsen ([Kn1], pp. 176–178).

1.3.1. Remark. We can try to modify this construction in order to be able to add an extra white point, instead of a black one. However, for card⁢B≥2,card𝐵2 we will not be able then to avoid the local analysis of the situation by referring to [Kn1]. In fact, points where ΔΔ intersects at least two B𝐵–sections simultaneously, will have to be treated anew.

body.p: Proof. Properness and smoothness follow by induction and Knudsen’s local analysis which we already invoked.

The statement about the combinatorial types is proved by induction as well. In fact, if everything is already proved for Cnsubscript𝐶𝑛, then we must look at a geometric fibre Cn,ssubscript𝐶𝑛𝑠 of Cnsubscript𝐶𝑛 and see what happens to it after the blow up described in 1.3. If ΔΔ intersects a smooth point of Cn,ssubscript𝐶𝑛𝑠, not coinciding with x0,s,x∞,ssubscript𝑥0𝑠subscript𝑥𝑠, nothing happens, except that we get a new black point on this fibre, and a new tail at the respective vertex of the dual graph. If ΔΔ intersects an intersection point of two neighboring components of Cn,ssubscript𝐶𝑛𝑠, then after blowing up these two components become disjoint, and we get a new component intersecting both of them, with a new black point on it. The linear structure of the graph is preserved. Finally, if ΔΔ intersects Cn,ssubscript𝐶𝑛𝑠 at x0,ssubscript𝑥0𝑠 or x∞,ssubscript𝑥𝑠, then after blowing up we will get a new end component, with x0,ssubscript𝑥0𝑠, resp. x∞,ssubscript𝑥𝑠 and the new black point on it. Thus the new combinatorial types will be linear and indexed by partitions of (n+1)𝑛1. To check that all partitions are obtained in this way, it suffices to remark that ΔΔ, being the relative diagonal, can intersect the fibre of a given type at any point.

In order to check the statement about the functor represented by L¯nsubscript¯𝐿𝑛 we apply the following inductive reasoning. For n=1𝑛1 the statement is almost obvious. In fact, let π:C→S:𝜋→𝐶𝑆 be a ({0,∞},{1})01–pointed stable curve of genus zero over T𝑇. From the stability it follows that all geometric fibres are projective lines. Since the three structure sections pairwise do not intersect, the family can be identified with ℙ1×Tsuperscriptℙ1𝑇 endowed with three constant sections. This means that it is induced by the trivial morphism T→L¯1→𝑇subscript¯𝐿1.

Assume that the statement is true for n𝑛. In order to prove it for n+1𝑛1, consider a ({0,∞},{1,…,n+1})01…𝑛1–pointed stable curve of genus zero π:C→T.:𝜋→𝐶𝑇 First of all, one can produce from it a ({0,∞},{1,…,n})01…𝑛–pointed stable curve of genus zero π:C′→T:𝜋→superscript𝐶′𝑇 obtained by forgetting xn+1subscript𝑥𝑛1 and subsequent stabilization. The respective map C′→C→superscript𝐶′𝐶 is given by the relative projective spectrum of the algebra ∑k=0∞π*⁢(𝒦⊗k)superscriptsubscript𝑘0subscript𝜋superscript𝒦tensor-productabsent𝑘 where 𝒦:=ωC/T⁢(x0+x1+…+xn+x∞)assign𝒦subscript𝜔𝐶𝑇subscript𝑥0subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛subscript𝑥. By induction, C′superscript𝐶′ is induced by a morphism p:T→L¯n:𝑝→𝑇subscript¯𝐿𝑛. Addition of an extra black section to C′superscript𝐶′ and subsequent stabilization boils down exactly to the construction 1.3 applied to C′/Tsuperscript𝐶′𝑇 which allows us to lift p𝑝 to a unique morphism q:T→L¯n+1.:𝑞→𝑇subscript¯𝐿𝑛1
Separatedness is checked by the standard deformation arguments.
The statement about renumbering follows from the description of the functor.
A similar adaptation of Knudsen’s arguments allows us to prove the remaining statements, and we leave them to the reader.

Notice that below we will give another direct description of the spaces L¯Bsubscript¯𝐿𝐵 and all the structure morphisms connecting them in terms of toric geometry. This will provide easy alternate proofs of their properties. Except for §4, we can restrict ourselves to this alternate description.

2.2.1. Remark. Dual graphs of the degenerate fibers of Cnsubscript𝐶𝑛 over L¯nsubscript¯𝐿𝑛 come with a natural orientation from x0subscript𝑥0 to x∞subscript𝑥. We could have allowed ourselves not to distinguish between the two white points, interchanging them by isomorphisms, but this would produce several upleasant consequences. First, our manifolds would become actual stacks, starting already with L¯1subscript¯𝐿1. Second, we would have lost the toric interpretation of these spaces. Third, and most important, we would meet an ambiguity in the definition of the multiplication between the homology spaces: see (3.5) below. With our choice, we can simply introduce the involution permuting x0subscript𝑥0 and x∞subscript𝑥 as a part of the structure and look how it interacts with other parts.

3.2.2. Pencils of flat connections related to Frobenius manifolds. Any solution to the Associativity Equations produces a pencil of flat connections.
To explain this we will use the geometric language due to B. Dubrovin (and the notation of [Ma], I.1.5). Consider a Frobenius manifold (M,g,∘)𝑀𝑔 where

is a (super)commutative associative multiplication on the tangent sheaf satisfying the potentiality condition, and g𝑔 is an invariant flat metric (no positivity condition is assumed, only symmetry and non–degeneracy). Denote by ∇0subscriptnormal-∇0 the Levi–Civita connection of g𝑔. Finally, denote by Anormal-A the operator obtained from the Frobenius multiplication in TMsubscriptnormal-T𝑀 ([Ma], I.1.4). In other words, consider the pencil of connections on F=TMnormal-Fsubscriptnormal-T𝑀 whose covariant derivatives are

This pencil is flat (see [Ma], Theorem I.1.5, p. 20). In fact, Bnormal-B written in a basis of ∇0subscriptnormal-∇0–flat coordinates and the respective flat vector fields is simply the matrix of the second derivatives of a local potential Φnormal-Φ (with one subscript raised). This is the first structure connection of M𝑀.

This pencil admits an infinite dimensional deformation: one should take the canonical extension of the potential to the large phase space and consider the coordinates with gravitational descendants as parameters of the deformation.
Another family of flat connections, this time on the
cotangent

sheaf of a Frobenius manifold M𝑀 admitting an Euler vector field E𝐸 (see [Ma], pp. 23–24), is defined as follows. Denote the scalar product on vector fields gˇλ⁢(X,Y):=g⁢((E-λ)-1∘X,Y).assignsubscriptnormal-ˇ𝑔𝜆𝑋𝑌𝑔superscript𝐸𝜆1𝑋𝑌 The inverse form induces a pencil of flat metrics on the cotangent sheaf, whose Levi–Civita connections however do not form a pencil of flat connections in our sense (see [Du1], Appendix D, and [Du3] for a general discussion of such setup). This is the second structure connection of M𝑀.

3.2.3. Flat coordinates and gravitational descendants. One can show that 1–forms on M𝑀 flat with respect to the dualized first structure connection are closed and therefore locally exact. Their integrals are called deformed flat coordinates. In [Du2], Example 2.3 and Theorem 2.2, B. Dubrovin gives explicit formal series in λ𝜆 (z𝑧 in his notation) for suitably normalized deformed flat coordinates. Coefficients of these series involve some correlators with gravitational descendants, namely those for which the non–trivial operators τpsubscript𝜏𝑝 are applied only at one point. In [KM2] and [Ma], VI.7.2, p.278, it was shown that two–point correlators of this kind determine a linear operator in the large phase space which transforms the modified correlators with descendants into non–modified ones (in any genus). This is important because apriori only modified correlators are defined for an arbitrary Cohomological Field Theory in the sense of [KM1], which is not necessarily quantum cohomology of a manifold.

3.2.4. Pencils of flat connections in a global setting. Pencils of flat connections appear also in the context of Simpson’s non–abelian Hodge theory. Briefly, consider a smooth projective manifold M𝑀 over Cnormal-C. One can define two moduli spaces, M⁢o⁢d1𝑀𝑜subscript𝑑1 and M⁢o⁢d2𝑀𝑜subscript𝑑2. The first one classifies flat connections (on variable vector bundles Fnormal-F with vanishing rational Chern classes) with semisimple Zariski closure of the monodromy group. The second one classifies semistable Higgs pairs (F,A)normal-Fnormal-A where Anormal-A is an operator as in 3.1, satisfying only the condition A∧A=0.normal-Anormal-A0 (In fact, one should only consider smooth points of the respective moduli spaces). N. Hitchin, C. Simpson, Fujiki et al. established that M⁢o⁢d1𝑀𝑜subscript𝑑1 and M⁢o⁢d2𝑀𝑜subscript𝑑2 are canonically isomorphic as C∞superscript𝐶–manifolds, but their complex structures I𝐼, J𝐽 are different, and together with K=I⁢J𝐾𝐼𝐽 produce a hypercomplex manifold.

P. Deligne has shown that the respective twistor space is precisely the moduli space of the pencils of flat connections on M𝑀 (where the Higgs complex structure corresponds to the point λ=∞𝜆 in our notation).
For details, see [Si].

§4. Stacks
and the extended modular operad

4.1. Introduction. The basic topological operad (M¯0;n+1,n≥2)subscriptnormal-¯𝑀0𝑛1𝑛2 of Quantum Cohomology lacks the n=1𝑛1 term which is usually formally defined as a point. We argued elsewhere (cf. [MaZ], sec. 7 and [Ma], VI.7.6) that it would be very desirable to find a non–trivial DM–stack which could play the role of M¯0;2subscriptnormal-¯𝑀02. There are several tests that such an object should pass:
a) It must be a semigroup (because for any operad Pnormal-P, the operadic multiplication makes a semigroup of P⁢(1)normal-P1).

b) It must be a part of an extended genus zero operad, say, (L~0;n+1,n≥1)subscriptnormal-~𝐿0𝑛1𝑛1 geometrically related to (M¯0;n+1,n≥2)subscriptnormal-¯𝑀0𝑛1𝑛2 in such a way that the theory of Gromov–Witten invariants with gravitational descendants could be formulated in this new context. In particular, it must geometrically explain two–point correlators with gravitational descendants.

c) In turn, the extended genus zero operad must be a part of an extended modular operad containing moduli spaces of arbitrary genus, in such a way that algebras over classical modular operads produce extended algebras.
In this section we will try to show that the space
passes at least a part of these tests. (Another candidate which might be interesting is lim⁢proj⁢L¯nnormal-limnormal-projsubscriptnormal-¯𝐿𝑛 with respect to the forgetful morphisms).

4.3.1. Combinatorial types of fibers. Let us remind that combinatorial types of classical (semi)stable curves with (only white) points labeled by a finite set A𝐴 are isomorphism classes of graphs, whose vertices are labeled by “genera” g≥0𝑔0 and tails are bijectively labeled by elements of A𝐴. Stability means that vertices of genus 0 bound ≥3absent3 flags, and vertices of genus 1 bound ≥1absent1 flags. Graphs can have edges with only one vertex, that is, simple loops. See [Ma], III.2 for more details.

Starting with such a graph Γnormal-Γ, or rather with its geometric realization, we can obtain an infinite series of graphs, which will turn out to be exactly combinatorial types of (semi)stable (A,B)𝐴𝐵–pointed curves that are fibers of the families described above. Namely, subdivide edges and tails of Γnormal-Γ by a finite set of new vertices of genus zero (on each edge or tail, this set may be empty). If a tail was subdivided, move the respective label (from A𝐴) to the newly emerged tail. Distribute the black tails labeled by elements of B𝐵 arbitrarily among the old and the new vertices. Call the resulting graph
a stringy stable combinatorial type

if it becomes stable after repainting black tails into white ones. Clearly, new vertices depict strings of P1superscriptnormal-P1’s stabilized by black points and eventually two special points on the end components.

It remains to see whether one can develop an extension of the Gromov–Witten invariants, preferably with descendants, to this context. The Remark 3.2.3 seems promising in this respect.
Appendix. Proof of the Technical Lemma

We break the proof into several steps whose content is indicated in the title of the corresponding subsection. An advice for the reader who might care to check the details: the most daunting task is to convince oneself that none of the alternatives has been inadvertently omitted.
